fields:
{{c1::Population health}} is at the intersection of {{c2::public health}} and {{c3::health care}}.

{{c2::Public health}} has a goal to {{c4::reduce costs}}

{{c3::Health care}} has a goal to improve {{c4::health outcomes}}
When patients are {{c1::non-compliant::compliant/non-complient}}, it is likely an indicator that there are social aspects that are effecting them

Definition of Health

{{c1::The state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity}}

Definition of Public Health

The activities that ensure {{c1::conditions in which people can be healthy}}. 

These activities include community wide efforts to {{c2::identify}}, {{c2::prevent}}, and {{c2::combat}} threats to the health of the public.

What influences public health?

Macro-social Forces
{{c1::Globalization}}
{{c2::Urbanization}}
{{c3::Population Aging}}
{{c4::Health Disparities}}

Globalization (Definition)

{{c1::Increasing interconnectedness of ideas, behaviors, resources, and human capital across the globe}}

Globalization

Challenes

Infectious disease outbreaks, fueled by {{c1::transcontinental travel}}, are no longer confined to 1 country or continent

{{c2::NCD epidemics}}, like obesity, fueled by adoption of unhealthy dietary practices and increasing availability of nutritionally poor, calorie dense foods

Ubinization

Challenges
Strains on urban infrastructure and planning affects {{c2::transportation}}, {{c4::sanitation}}, {{c3::green}} space

{{c1::Migration}} patters affect family structure - very young and very old remain behind in rural areas

{{c1::Screening}} is the identification of an {{c2::unrecognized}} disease or risk factor

Used in a population to detect a {{c3::disease}} in seemingly healthy, asymptomatic people
The purpose of {{c1::screening}} is to prevent {{c2::death and suffering}} from common diseases, not just to {{c3::find diseases early}}

Benefits of screening

{{c1::Identify diseases early}}
{{c2::Early intervestion and management}}
{{c3::less death and suffering}}

Risks of Screening

{{c1::Overdiagnosis}} - You find what you're looking for

{{c1::Misdiagnosis}} - Find the wrong thing

{{c2::Flase sense of security}}

{{c2::Increased anxiety}}

{{c3::Cost}}

Risk of additional {{c3::invasive procedures}}
USPSTF requires evidence that the screening will be {{c1::cost effective}}, {{c2::timely}}, and {{c3::save lives}}
The USPSTF suggests genetic screen with breast cancer when there is a {{c1::family history}} of breast cancer
USPSTF gives a A rating for {{c1::colon cancer}} screening because it is a good sensitive test
USPSTF suggestion for {{c1::cevical cancer}} is to screen between ages {{c2::21}}-{{c2::65}} with a {{c3::pap smear}} and then from ages {{c2::30}}+ to do a {{c3::pap smear}} with a {{c3::HPV test}}
USPSTF suggests for screening prostate cancer is {{c1::not advised::advised/not advised}} for males over {{c2::70}}

Sketchy Pharmacology: Neuro/Psych 

Bupropion inhibits the reuptake of {{c1::norepinephrine}} and {{c1::dopamine}}
This results in an overall stimulatory effect, thus making it useful as a 2nd line treatment for depression associated with hypersomnia and low energy
Nicotine withdrawal may be treated using nicotine replacement, {{c1::bupropion}}, or {{c2::varenicline}}

withdrawal symptoms include irritability, anxiety, restlessness, and difficulty concentrating 

NDRI & NDRA

NAChR partial agonist
What is the mechanism of action of Bupropion?
Inhibits NE and Dopamine reuptake
What is the mechanism of action of Bupropion?
Inhibits NE and Dopamine reuptake
{{c1::Tabacco}} smoking is the single most {{c2::preventable}} cause of death
{{c1::Smoking}} is responsible for {{c2::87::}}% of {{c3::lung::organ}} cancer deaths
90% of adult smokers start before the age of {{c1::18}}
{{c2::50}}% of teens try smoking at least once by the {{c1::12th::1st-12th?}} grade
Rate of cancers drops by {{c1::50}}% {{c2::10}} years after quitting smoking

Tabacco Cessation: How to do it

2 Strategies: 5 A's

{{c1::Ask}}, {{c2::Advise}}, {{c3::assess}}, {{c4::assist}}, {{c5::arrange follow up}}

OR 

{{c1::Ask}}, {{c2::advise}}, {{c3::refer}}

The five stages of change

1. {{c1::Precontemplation}}
2. {{c1::Contemplation}}
3. {{c1::Preparation}}
4. {{c1::Action}}
5. {{c1::Maintenance}}

The five stages of change

1. {{c1::Precontemplation}}
2. {{c2::Contemplation}}
3. {{c3::Preparation}}
4. {{c4::Action}}
5. {{c5::Maintenance}}

When assess a tabacco user's addiction ensure to look into

1. {{c1::Level of dependence}}
2. {{c2::Past Behavior}}
3. {{c3::Readiness}}
4. {{c4::Conviction}}
5. {{c5::Confidence}}

Three methods of prevention

{{c1::Primary Prevention}}

{{c2::Safety net programs and secondary prevention}}

{{c3::Acute medical care and tertiary prevention}}

How do disparities arise?

Differences in the {{c1::quality of care}} received within the health care system

Differences in {{c2::access to health care}}, including preventive and curative services

Differences in {{c3::life opportunities}}, {{c3::exposures}}, and {{c3::stresses}} that result in differences in underlying health status

What is racism?

A system of structuring {{c1::opportunity}} and assigning {{c2::value}} based on the social interpretation of how one looks (which is what we call "race")

Effecs of rasicm

1. {{c1::Unfairly disadvantes}} some individuals and communities
2. {{c2::Unfairly advantages}} other individuals and communities
3. Saps the strength of the whole society through the waste of {{c3::human resources}}

Levels of Racism

{{c1::Institutionalized}}
{{c1::Personally-mediated}}
{{c1::Internalized}}

Institutionalized Racism

Differential access to the goods, services, and opportunities of {{c1::society}}, by “race”

Adult Obesity

BMI = {{c1::weight / height^2}}

Underweight: {{c1::< 18.5}}
Normal: {{c1::18.5 - 24.9}}
Overweight: {{c1::25 - 29.9}}
Obese: {{c1::≥ 30}}

Obese Class 1: {{c2::30 - 34.9}}
Obese Class 2: {{c2::35 - 39.9}}
Obese Class 3: {{c2::≥ 40}}

Pediatric Obesity

Pediatric obesity is calculated as a {{c1::percentile}} to account for the normal differences in {{c2::body fat}} between boys and girls at different ages

As children are growing the measurments used to track their growth are different

There are two different growth charts: one from the WHO and the CDC

{{c1::WHO}}: for youth {{c2::0 - 2}} years old
{{c1::CDC}}: for youth {{c2::2 - 19}} years old
Globablly, {{c1::Mexico}} and the {{c1::US}} are the two leading countries of obesity
Obesity disproportionately affects genders and races. Currently obesity affects {{c1::hispanic boys}} and {{c1::non-hispanic black girls}}

Physical consequences of obesity:

{{c1::Mortality}}
{{c2::Cardiovascular disease}}
{{c3::Cancer}}

{{c4::Hypertension}}
{{c5::Osteoarthritis}}
{{c6::Lipid diease}}
{{c7::Type 2 Diabetes}}

{{c8::Sleep apnea}}
{{c9::Gallbladder disease}}
{{c10::Stroke}}
MCC HOLD SGS

There are two forms of fat people shape

{{c1::Apple}} and {{c1::pear}} shaped fat people

{{c1::Apple}} shaped fat people are at {{c2::increased::increased/decreased}} risk for chronic disease than {{c1::pear}} shaped fat people

{{c1::Apple}}-shaped fat people is have more {{c2::viseral}} fat
{{c1::Pear}}-shaped fat people have more {{c2::subcutaneous}} fat

Psychosocial consequences of obesity

{{c1::Anxiety}}
{{c1::Social isolation}}
{{c1::Despression}}
{{c1::Acaemic performance (lower)}}
{{c1::Quality of Life (lower)}}
{{c1::Self-esteem (lower)}}
ASDAQS (kind of like NASDAQ)

{{c1::Anxiety}}

Economic consequences of obesity

{{c1::Abesneteeism & Presenteeism}} - Obese individuals tend to miss work more, and when they are at work, they are more limited

{{c1::Direct and indirect medical costs}} - obesity costs money

Pediatric Obesity

Overweight: {{c1::85 - 95th percentile}}
Obese: {{c2::≥ 95th percentile}}

Subsystems within the bioecological framework

{{c1::The individual}}
{{c2::Microsystem}}
{{c3::Mesosystem}}
{{c4::Exosystem}}
{{c5::Macrosystem}}
{{c6::Chronosystem}}

Subsystems within the bioecological framework

{{c1::The individual}}
{{c1::Microsystem}}
{{c1::Mesosystem}}
{{c1::Exosystem}}
{{c1::Macrosystem}}
{{c1::Chronosystem}}

The bioecological framework

The {{c1::microsystem}} is anything that directly influences the individual

examples are:
School, Family, church group

The bioecological framework

The {{c1::mesosystem}} is the interaction of microsystems

examples are:
how school experiences are related to family experiences

The bioecological framework

The {{c1::exosystem}} is things that indirectly affect the individual

examples are:
Mother gets a raise at work, increased travel causes marital strain

Maternal vs Paternal Associations with child height and weight

Both {{c1::maternal}} and {{c1::paternal}} lines are associated with {{c2::height}}, but only the {{c1::maternal}} line is associated with {{c2::BMI}}

The Developmental cascade model of paediatric obesity

Has 4 stages:

{{c1::Prenatal-infant}} stage
{{c2::Toddler-Preschooler}} stage
{{c3::School-age child}} stage
{{c4::Adolescent-Teenager}} stage

The Developmental cascade model of paediatric obesity

Has 4 stages:

{{c1::Prenatal-infant}} stage
{{c1::Toddler-Preschooler}} stage
{{c1::School-age child}} stage
{{c1::Adolescent-Teenager}} stage

Prenatal-infant stage

This stage is very dependant on {{c1::maternal}} health

Toddler-Preschooler stage

Children in this stage experience a {{c1::adiposity rebound}}. 

In early development, the average {{c2::BMI}} dips and then rebounds.

If a child dips and rebounds {{c3::earlier::earlier/later}}, they are at an {{c4::increased::increased/decreased}} risk for obesity
